Intro.p: An enumeration of valid SIF DataObject names, to be included in Object References

Value.Text: An organisation other than a Provider
A recognised provider of education services such as ECE Service, School or TEI
A recognised relationship between two providers of education services.
A person who enrols at a Provider
A person who is part ofa Student's whānau
A relationship between a person who is part of a Student's whānau and that Student
The record of an enrolment relationship between a Student and a Provider.
Record of a Student's attendance or absence from school or class on a particular day.
Aggregate summary of Student's attendance and absence from school across a particular time period.

CodeSet.Intro: Regions of New Zealand defined by Ministry of Education for administrative purposes. (North to South):
Codes describing the nature of an Education Organisation; for Schools this indicates the schooling levels offered.
Codes describing the nature of a person or organisation's communications channel.

Value.Description: Typically refers to the home page for an entity

CodeSet.Intro: Codes describing acceptable usage of a person or organisation's communication channel.

Value.Description: Allows the school to decide which of a caregiver's communication channels is to be used when reporting a medical incident occuring to the learner.
Allows the school to decide which of a caregiver's communication channels is to be used when sending an SMS (or TXT) message.
Allows the school to decide which of the caregiver's communication channels is to be used when reporting a learner's unexplained absence.
Allows the caregiver to decide which of the school's communication channels is to be used when notifying of a learner's intended absence.

CodeSet.Intro: Codes describing a standardised role held by a contact within an organisation.
Codes describing state legislated policies that can be adopted by schools.

Value.Text: New entrants policy choice whereby children may start school on or soon after their 5th birthday
New entrants policy choice whereby children may start school only on specific notified dates after their 5th birthday.

CodeSet.Intro: The authority by which a Provider is authorised to provide education services.

Value.Description: Owned by another organisation, funded from Vote Education.

CodeSet.Intro: Criteria for defining the nature of a school.

Intro.p: A description of the gender of students that the school accepts for a certain year level or other instructional grouping.
Describes the role the source Provider plays in a relationship between a pair of Providers.

Value.Description: Source provider sends Students to the matching 'Host School' for individual classes.
Source provider hosts Students from the matching 'Client School' for individual classes.
Most Students from the source provider enrol at the matching 'Receiving School' once they have completed the last year of instruction conducted by the 'Contributing School'.
Most Students from related provider enrol at the 'Receiving School' once they have completed the last year of instruction conducted by the matching 'Contributing School'.

Intro.p: A description of the gender identity students use to describe themselves. Sourced from NZ Standard for Gender Identity

Value.Description: Level 1 Code
Level 1 Code
Level 1 Code
Level 2 Code
Level 2 Code
Level 2 Code
Level 2 Code
Level 2 Code
Level 2 Code

Intro.p: The citizenship or residency status of a person, principally recorded in order to determine eligibility for education services hence limited to indicating New Zealand, Australian or Other residency.

Value.Description: Indicates a residency other than NZ or Australia

Intro.p: The means by which an identity and eligibility status for education services is verified. Principally refers to an identity document type (eg passport) but may also include a type of business decision taken to accept an assertion of identity and eligibility status (eg principal discretion).
A standardised method of describing the usage of a language by a person, potentially indicating capability and preference for the language.
Language refers to recognised human communication systems, typically oral and/or written.
Sourced from Statistics NZ - Language Standard Classification 1999 v2.0.0

Value.Text: Pidgins and Creoles not further defined
Pidgins and Creoles not elsewhere classified

Intro.p: Ethnicity is the ethnic group or groups that people identify with or feel they belong to. Ethnicity is a measure of cultural affiliation, as opposed to race, ancestry, nationality or citizenship. Ethnicity is self perceived and people can belong to more than one ethnic group.
The permissible values consists of any value from the Statistics NZ - Ethnicity New Zealand Standard Classification 2005 v2.0.0 Depending on usage, ethnicity may be defined at levels 1 to 4.

An iwi, or Māori tribe, is one of the largest kinship groupings and is generally made up of several hapū that are all descended from a common ancestor. Hapū are clusters of whānau where the whānau is usually an extended family grouping consisting of children, parents, often grandparents, and other closely related kin.
The permissible values consists of any value from the Statistics NZ - Iwi and Iwi related groups statistical standard v1.0.0.0

Value.Text: Ngāpuhi ki Whaingaroa-Ngāti Kahu ki Whaingaroa
Ngāti Porou ki Harataunga ki Mataora
Waikato/Te Rohe Pōtae (Waikato/King Country) Region Iwi
Tauranga Moana/Mātaatua (Bay of Plenty) Region Iwi
Te Tai Rāwhiti (East Coast) Region Iwi
Ngāti Kahungunu ki Tamakinui a Rua
Rangitāne o Tamaki nui ā Rua
Ngāti Tama ki Te Upoko o Te Ika (Te Whanganui-a-Tara/Wellington)
Te Waipounamu/Wharekauri (South Island/Chatham Islands) Region Iwi
Ngāti Apa ki Te Rā Tō
Confederations and Waka, iwi not named
Hauraki / Pare Hauraki, iwi not named
Tūranganui a Kiwa, iwi not named
Te Tauihu o Te Waka a Māui, iwi not named
Hapū affiliated to more than one iwi
Hapū affiliated to more than one iwi
Te Tai Tokerau/Tāmaki-makaurau Region, Iwi not named
Waikato/Te Rohe Pōtae Region, Iwi not named
Te Arawa/Taupō Region, Iwi not named
Tauranga Moana/Mātaatua Region, Iwi not named
Te Tai Rāwhiti Region, Iwi not named
Te Matau-a-Māui/Wairarapa Region, Iwi not named
Manawatū/Horowhenua/Te Whanganui-a-Tara Region, Iwi not named
Te Waipounamu/Wharekauri Region, Iwi not named

Intro.p: The status of a Student Provider Enrolment.

Description.p: The enrolment is a 'pre-enrolment' application, and has not yet been accepted or declined by the provider.
The 'pre-enrolment' application has been accepted by the Provider, and has not yet been taken up, or become ACTIVE.
The 'pre-enrolment' application has been declined by the Provider, or by the Student, prior to becoming an ACTIVE enrolment.
The enrolment has been accepted by the Provider, taken up by the Student, and the Student has attended their first day.

Value.Description: The Student has left the Provider, after the enrolment was made ACTIVE

Description.p: The 'pre-enrolment' has been accepted by the Provider, taken up by the Student, and the Student has attended their first day; but the enrolment is unable to be set to ACTIVE, because there is still an ACTIVE enrolment for the Student at a (previous) provider.
Once the blocking Provider has put their enrolment to WITHDRAWN, this enrolment can be moved to 'ACTIVE'

Intro.p: Enrolment Exit code, derived from codeset used in School Roll Returns.

Value.Text: Transferred to another school in New Zealand.

Value.Description: Applies to students >= 16yrs old
Applies to students <16yrs old
Applies to students <16yrs old

Intro.p: Eligibility Criteria code, describes the criteria used to determine the eligibility of a Student for enrolment and MoE funding.

Value.Text: NZ Citizen (Incl. Tokelau, The Cook Is., Niue)

Value.Description: Includes Australian permanent residents

Value.Text: Student on Government approved student exchange scheme

Intro.p: Student classification for MoE funding purposes.

Codes in this list are hierarchical. Students can only be allocated one TYPE code (even though they may belong to more than one of the groups listed below). To allocate a code to an individual student, start at the top of the list and work down. Use the first code that applies to the student.

Value.Description: An International student who meets full tuition costs on their own or from funds provided to them by sponsors other than NZAID.
A student who is enrolled in an Alternative Education programme, for Funding Year Level they should be reported only between Year 9 and Year 13 (inclusive).
A student (and dependants) studying in New Zealand under an exchange programme approved by the New Zealand Government.
Code to be used for students attending on Roll Count Day, but not paying fee and not funded; e.g. students with Eligibility Criteria “28 Day Waiver” and “Extended 28 Day Waiver”.

Description.p: A student who has returned to school following a break of at least 1 year and is at least 19 years old on 1 January of the Roll count year.
EXAMPLE: Roll count year = 2017 if student is 19 years old on 1 Jan 2017 their student type = AD if there has been a break in their learning cycle.
A student who has continued at school and is at least 19 on 1 January of the Roll count year.
EXAMPLE: Roll count year = 2017 if student is 19 years old on 1 January 2017 their student type = RA as there has not been a break in the students learning cycle.

Value.Description: A New Zealand student or a student treated for funding and staffing purposes as a New Zealand student who is also not yet 19 years at 1 Jan of the roll count year. This includes students in general classrooms and those in special needs units.

Value.Text: Teen Parent Regular Student, over max. roll
Value.Description: A regular student (i.e. a student aged under 19 years at 1 January of the roll count year) who meets the eligibility criteria, but whose enrolment would cause the roll of the TPU to exceed the set maximum.

Value.Text: Teen Parent Adult Student, over max. roll
Value.Description: An adult student who is enrolled in a Teen Parent Unit (TPU) where the enrolment at the TPU has continued beyond the end of the year in which the student reached 19 years old. The enrolment of this student causes the roll of the TPU to exceed the set maximum.

Value.Text: Returning Adult Student attending Teen Parent Unit
Value.Description: A student enrolling at the TPU as an adult student (i.e. was at least 19 on 1st January of the year when they first enrolled at the TPU), and who fits within the TPU’s maximum roll.

Value.Text: Teen Parent Eligible and Enrolled Regular Student
Value.Description: A student who is enrolled in a Teen Parent Unit (TPU) and is at least 19 years old on 1 January of the current year. These students may continue to be enrolled in the TPU after the end of the year in which they turn 19, their Student Type however will then be changed to TPRAE – Teen Parent Enrolled Continuing Adult Student.

Value.Text: Teen Parent Eligibile and Enrolled Adult Student
Value.Description: A student who is enrolled in a Teen Parent Unit (TPU) where the enrolment at the TPU has continued beyond the end of the year in which the student reached 19 years old.
A student who attends this school for some courses but is enrolled at another school where a majority of instruction occurs.
Student who is in a Satellite class of a Special School.
A student who is not attending the school on the day of the roll count and there is no documentation to support their absence from the school.
Student is enrolled in a separately funded unit.

Intro.p: The type of exchange scheme for student enrolment where the Eligibility Criteria is "Student on Government approved exchange scheme" (5).

Value.Text: Student Exchange Australia New Zealand Ltd.

Intro.p: The reson for non-attendance at school, or non-attendance in class.
